issues.title: Missing Parent Notification Requirements
issues.description: California Education Code requires districts to establish procedures for notifying parents when controversial issues will be discussed in class. Neither the BP nor AR contains any provision for parent notification, which is a statutory requirement that protects parental rights in education.

legal_citations.text: No teacher shall give instruction and no school district shall sponsor any activity which reflects adversely upon persons because of their race, sex, color, creed, handicap, national origin, or ancestry. However, this section shall not restrict the presentation of the facts of history or the discussion of controversial issues which may have political, economic, or social significance if such instruction or activities do not reflect adversely upon persons because of their race, sex, color, creed, handicap, national origin, or ancestry, and if such presentations are made in a balanced manner.

issues.required_language: The district shall establish procedures to notify parents/guardians in advance when controversial issues will be discussed in their child's classroom, providing reasonable opportunity for parents to review materials and request alternative assignments if desired.

issues.title: Missing Complaint Process
issues.description: The policy lacks a clear process for handling complaints or concerns from parents, students, or community members regarding the presentation of controversial issues. This is essential for due process and accountability.

legal_citations.text: The governing board of any school district shall prescribe and enforce rules not inconsistent with law or with the rules prescribed by the State Board of Education, for its own government and the government of the schools under its jurisdiction.

issues.required_language: Any complaint regarding the presentation of controversial issues shall be addressed through the district's uniform complaint procedures as outlined in BP/AR 1312.3. Parents, students, or community members may file complaints with the principal or superintendent regarding alleged violations of this policy.

issues.title: Incomplete Protected Class Categories
issues.description: The AR references protected categories but omits some classes protected under current California law, such as gender identity, gender expression, and religion, which have been added to anti-discrimination statutes since 2010.

legal_citations.text: No person shall be subjected to discrimination on the basis of disability, gender, gender identity, gender expression, nationality, race or ethnicity, religion, sexual orientation, or any other characteristic that is contained in the definition of hate crimes set forth in Section 422.55 of the Penal Code, including immigration status, in any program or activity conducted by an educational institution that receives, or benefits from, state financial assistance, or enrolls pupils who receive state student financial aid.

issues.required_language: The discussion does not reflect adversely upon persons because of their race, sex, color, creed, religion, sexual orientation, gender identity, gender expression, national origin, ancestry, disability, or occupation.

issues.title: Missing Reference to Academic Freedom
issues.description: The policy should acknowledge the balance between academic freedom and appropriate boundaries, particularly given California's strong academic freedom protections for educators within appropriate pedagogical limits.

legal_citations.text: Teachers have the right to present controversial issues in the classroom if the presentation is related to the subject matter being taught and is conducted in a balanced manner that does not promote any particular viewpoint.

issues.required_language: The Board recognizes that academic freedom includes the right of teachers to present controversial issues that are pedagogically appropriate and related to the curriculum, while maintaining professional responsibility to present multiple perspectives in a balanced manner.
